last_post.content:
AI getting even weirder: "MusicLM: Generating Music From Text" from a team at Google research

Generates audio clips from prompts like "A fusion of reggaeton and electronic dance music, with a spacey, otherworldly sound. Induces the experience of being lost in space, and the music would be designed to evoke a sense of wonder and awe, while being danceable."

No interactive demo, but this link has a huge number of examples to listen to:

https://google-research.github.io/seanet/musiclm/examples/

Paper: https://www.arxiv-vanity.com/papers/2301.11325/

I have become anecdotally aware of several (smaller) mastodon instances that are considering shutting down because they cannot afford their server bills.

If you are a #mastodonadmin of an instance that is 1000+ users and considering shutting down please reach out to me.

We may be willing to take over your instance and save your users if you are compliant with the Mastodon Server Covenenant (https://joinmastodon.org/covenant)

Mastodon founder and CEO Eugen Rochko tells Engadget: “Third party applications are incredibly valuable for a platform because that's where the power users go … it benefits everybody because the power users are the people who create the content that everybody reads.”

THANK YOU 👏👏👏

https://www.engadget.com/twitter-client-developers-fleeing-twitter-mastodon-130031551.html

title: Google Changes Appeals Process for Suspected Child Abuse Images

last_post.content: After I did the story about the dad whose Google account was closed and deleted for taking a photo of his naked toddler for the doctor, I heard from a distraught mother in Colorado who was going through the same thing and didn't know why. Her Google account was disabled, taking with it her wedding photos, videos of her 9yo son growing up, tax documents, email and everything else. And she had no idea why. She was in tears. "It feels like my house burned down," she told me: https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/30/technology/google-appeals-change.html

title: Inside Japan’s long experiment in automating elder care

last_post.content:
After many years of research and much money spent, #robots for elder care seem like a failure in Japan.
“In short, the machines failed to save labor. The care robots themselves required care: they had to be moved around, maintained, cleaned, booted up, operated […]
Instead of saving time for staff to do more of the human labor of social and emotional care, the robots actually reduced the scope for such work.“
https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/01/09/1065135/japan-automating-eldercare-robots/

Here are the lighthouses of Europe.

The map is even better than it might seem at first glance: the colors are the real colors, the patterns are the real patterns, and the size of the dots is the distance at which each light is visible.

Made with @openstreetmap, Leaflet, and the Overpass API.

https://geodienst.github.io/lighthousemap/

From the Geodienst researchers of Groningen University (NL), via Ethan Mollick

#lighthouse #geojson #openstreetmap #map

title: Characterizing the Google Books Corpus: Strong Limits to Inferences of Socio-Cultural and Linguistic Evolution

last_post.content: Arguments that draw broad cultural inferences from the frequency of words in Google Books should be approached with considerable skepticism — new article in PLOS One. [Ed note: actually this was 2015!] (The article notes that genre-stabilized subsets like English Fiction are less subject to distortion.) https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0137041#pone-0137041-g013

title: ‘The Terraformers’ is a dazzling look at the distant future

last_post.content:
A review of The Terraformers in @WashingtonPost! "The reader of Annalee Newitz’s third novel, “The Terraformers,” will surely walk away, stunned and bedazzled…this generously overstuffed tale has enough ideas and incidents to populate half a dozen lesser science fiction books. But the reading experience is never clotted or tedious, never plagued by extraneous detours…[Newitz has] gifted us a vibrant, quirky vision of endless potential earned by heroism, love and wit."

https://www.washingtonpost.com/books/2023/01/27/annalee-newitz-terraformers/

title: Is Your Future Distributed? Welcome to the Fediverse! - TidBITS

last_post.content:
These two Tidbits articles by @glennf are probably the best explanations on the fediverse and mastodon I’ve seen. Most others id end up glazing over trying to read.

Recommend sharing them with any curious what this stuff is and how they work.

https://tidbits.com/2023/01/27/is-your-future-distributed-welcome-to-the-fediverse/

https://tidbits.com/2023/01/27/mastodon-a-new-hope-for-social-networking/

#Fediverse #Mastodon

When @atomicpoet and others talk about the need for everyone to think of the #Fediverse way beyond #Mastodon or Twitter-like app replacements, I agree 1,000 percent.

Here is a whole class of #Fediverse apps I'd love to see: socially connected, secure but shareable small datasets and libraries and collections.

cc: @simon

https://tomcritchlow.com/2023/01/27/small-databases/

@paula
@AxelPolleres

Seit mehreren Jahren gibt es bereits https://socialhub.activitypub.rocks/

Vor allem gibt es die W3C Social Web Incubator Community Group
https://www.w3.org/community/socialcg/

Eine der drängenden Hauptaufgaben ist die Vereinigung der fragmentierten Community und Plattformen. Siehe dazu u.a.
https://socialhub.activitypub.rocks/t/poll-socialhub-scope-and-purpose/2843/12 und https://github.com/swicg/general/issues/29

@vicki You asked about the difference between search and recsys. Here is a great answer IMHO:
"an AI-driven search tool—that is, a tool that won't show you what you ask for, but rather, what it thinks you should see." from https://www.wired.com/story/tiktok-platforms-cory-doctorow/

With search you drive, with recsys you are driven.

"Cistercian Numbers" are incredibly cool

It's a rare numeric system designed by 13th century monks

Each number is a based on a single vertical stick, with patterns you draw in all four quadrants off it -- top right, top left, bottom right, bottom left

A single glyph can represent a number from 1 to 9,999

It's in my recent weekly "Linkfest" newsletter, here: https://buttondown.email/clivethompson/archive/linkfest-3-cisterian-numbers-robots-that-hug-and/

Want to subscribe? Pay-what-you-want here: https://buttondown.email/clivethompson

I call it "The opposite of doomscrolling"

title: From 'Seinfeld' to Steve Jobs: What Was Normcore & What Is It Now?

last_post.content:
“Normcore moves away from a coolness that relies on difference to a post-authenticity coolness that opts into sameness. But instead of appropriating an aestheticized version of the mainstream, it just cops to the situation at hand. To be truly Normcore, you need to understand that there's no such thing as normal.”
https://www.highsnobiety.com/p/what-is-normcore/
